com.hippikon.security
Interface PermissionSet

All Superinterfaces:
java.io.Serializable
All Known Implementing Classes:
DefaultPermissionSet
public interface PermissionSet
extends java.io.Serializable

The PermissionSet interface represents a set of flags (or an ACL entry) for a ProtectedResource. Each ProtectedResource may have many PermissionSet instances representing the permissions assigned to different principals such as a role or user-type.

The interface defines a mechanism of combining multiple PermissionSet objects that performs a logical OR operation to find the complete set of permissions of a single user accessing a ProtectedResource within an AuthorizationContext. The user may play multiple roles or have some special association with the ProtectedResource (such as the instance creator).

The user type logic is encapsulated in Policy implementations that are bound to ProtectedResource objects at deploy time using a hippikon.product.[productID].resource.policies file for the application. PermissionSet rules must be defined in a PolicyStore for an application.

Different mechanisms for definint PermissionSet rules may vary, but the preferred way is to use an XML file that conforms to the Hippikon DTD. See the Hippikon documentation for deatails.

To obtain the PermissionSet for a ProtectedResource, clients must use the Policy static method 

 PermissionsFactory.getPermissions(ProtectedResource res, AuthorizationContext ctx)

Note there are no mutator methods defined for the interface. Application logic may not change PermissionSet objects once returned from the PermissionsFactory. All authorization logic must be encapsulated in a single package for an application and defined within the Policy implementations for specialized ProtectedResource classes.

Semantics The semantic meaning of each permission flag is as follows:

canCreate() : new instances of a ProtectedResource may be created. In cases where no instances are ever created (an abstract class for example), the permission should not be enabled.

canRead() : the read-only public methods and attributes of a ProtectedResource may be accessed. For most cases, this means the object can be retrieved and displayed in a user interface. The instance may also participate in a remote transaction (XML/SOAP for instance) provided the user granted READ initiates the operation.

canWrite() : the internal data of an existing ProtectedResource instance may be modified. The internal data should not include any fields that store state information.

canControl() : changes to the internal state or lifecycle of the object can be affected. Examples could include moving an object from IN_ACTIVE to ACTIVE through some operation provided on the ProtectedResource public interface.

canDelete() : an instance may be permenantly deleted. In the case the object includes dependent objects through a composition assocation, all dependent objects recursively must also be deleted recursively (cascading delete). This permission also allows dependent objects to be deleted without the parent being affected (for example, deleting a note).

Since:
JDK 1.2.2

Method Summary
 boolean canControl()
          Returns true if the CONTROL flag of the PermissionSet is enabled
 boolean canCreate()
          Returns true if the CREATE flag of the PermissionSet is enabled
 boolean canDelete()
          Returns true if the DELETE flag of the PermissionSet is enabled
 boolean canRead()
          Returns true if the READ flag of the PermissionSet is enabled
 boolean canWrite()
          Returns true if the WRITE flag of the PermissionSet is enabled
